entry.title: How the Aussie Trades Are Prioritising Mental Health
entry.summary: Mental health has become a major talking point in the construction and trade industries across Australia. For years, the tough-it-out culture among tradies meant mental wellbeing often took a backseat. But times are changing. Today, more and more Aussie tradies and employers are acknowledging that mental health is just as important as physical safety on the job. In this article, we dive into how the trades are taking mental health seriously, what challenges workers face, and the support systems making a real difference. Why Mental Health Matters in the Trades? For tradies, the job can be physically demanding, fast-paced, and mentally exhausting. Long hours, tight deadlines, unpredictable weather, and job insecurity can all take a toll. Many tradies also work in isolation or small teams, whâ€¦

entry.title: Top WordPress Maintenance Tasks You Shouldn't Ignore
entry.summary: Running a WordPress website entails more than just establishing it and then leaving it alone. Like any digital asset, your WordPress site requires regular care and attention to ensure it performs optimally, stays secure, and delivers a seamless experience for visitors. Ignoring basic maintenance tasks can lead to issues like slow loading speeds, outdated content, broken links, security vulnerabilities, and even complete site crashes. One of the most critical tasks in your WordPress maintenance plan is regularly backing up your website. Backups ensure that you can restore your site to a previous version without losing valuable data in case of a crash, hack, or accidental deletion. Best Practices: Schedule automatic daily or weekly backups depending on how often your site is updated. Use relâ€¦

entry.title: Building a Simple Java To-Do List Application
entry.summary: One of the most effective ways to learn Java is through hands-on projects. Creating a simple to-do list application helps beginners not only grasp basic Java syntax but also enhances their understanding of graphical interfaces, object-oriented programming, and simple data storage. This article explains how to build a basic to-do list app step by step using Java. Project Overview Preparation Task Structure Design User Interface Design After a user inputs a task and clicks the "Add" button, the task is added to the list. Clicking on a task and then pressing "Delete" removes it, while clicking "Complete" changes its status. These actions are managed through event listeners, and the task display updates in real time based on user interaction. Program Logic and Interaction To improve usability, the app can be enhanced to save tasks to a local file and automatically load them when the application starts. This feature ensures users wonâ€™t lose their tasks after closing the app and can be implemented using Javaâ€™s file I/O classes. Conclusion Building a simple Java to-do list application is a great way to practice core programming skills such as object-oriented design, event handling, GUI development, and data manipulation. Although this is a small project, it effectively demonstrates how Java can be used to build desktop applications. If you wish to expand the functionality, you can add features like task categories, due dates, or priority levels to create a more powerful task manager.

entry.title: AWS Trust Policy Complete Guide: How to Control IAM Role Access in 2025
entry.summary:
Table of Contents
Introduction What is AWS Trust Policy? Trust Policy vs. Permission Policy How trust Policy Works Common Use Cases of Trust Policies Best Practices for Trust Policies Conclusion References Most AWS architects and developers create and use IAM roles but do not understand how the permissions described in the policies attached to a role are assigned to principals. The permissions assigned to the principal are always temporary and short-lived. These short-lived credentials are generated by AWS Security Token Service (STS), but wait â€“ what ensures that the right principals assume a role? In this article we will look at AWS Trust Policy, the security gatekeeper that ensures that the right principal can assume a role to perform its actions. A trust policy is a type of AWS resoâ€¦

entry.title: Code Quality & Testing Automation
entry.summary: Let me tell you a little story. It was a chilly Tuesday morning. I pushed what I thought was a â€œharmlessâ€ update to a legacy payment moduleâ€”half-commented in a language no one speaks anymore (possibly Elvish?). An hour later, our production server began throwing errors like it was auditioning for a disaster movie. Thatâ€™s the day I truly understood why code quality and automated testing matter. And thatâ€™s the day I almost fled tech to become a barista. Code quality is like personal hygieneâ€”if you donâ€™t maintain it, things get gross fast. Sure, it technically still works, but no one wants to be near it. Great code is readable, maintainable, testable, and doesnâ€™t make the next developer cry. Bad code? Youâ€™ll know it. Itâ€™s the kind with 12 nested if statements, variables named x1 through x7, aâ€¦

entry.title: Have We Lost Our Way? (A Developer's Small Crisis of Confidence)
entry.summary:
There was a time when we built things to last. Now we build MVPs to maybe survive the quarter. This isnâ€™t a post about how everything used to be better. Itâ€™s just an observation â€” and maybe a quiet protest â€” about how easy it is to confuse activity for progress when the rituals of delivery become more important than the value delivered. Somewhere along the way, we started measuring the number of tickets closed instead of whether anything actually got better. We replaced architecture with story points. We replaced meaningful iteration with ceremonies so performative they deserve their own Oscars category. We got really good at â€œvelocityâ€ and forgot that shipping garbage faster is not the same as improvement. â€œDeliver working software.â€
Remember that one? It used to be a principle. Now itâ€™s just something you hear right before someone tells you theyâ€™re rewriting a service because the old one was written in the â€œwrongâ€ language. Iâ€™m not saying waterfall was better.
Iâ€™m saying weâ€™ve swung too far the other way. Where once we spent six months planning a login form, now we spend six months pretending not to plan anything â€” and somehow end up with three frontends, five services, and nothing reusable. Every generation of devs thinks theyâ€™re the first to see the mess.
But weâ€™ve been here before. And weâ€™ll be here again. The best we can do is notice it earlier, name it honestly, and maybe do a little less damage next time. ðŸ—‚ Originally posted at thecynical.dev â€” a side blog for developers whoâ€™ve survived legacy Java, agile transformations, and frameworks that promised joy but delivered YAML.

entry.title: Coding Is Gardening: A Developerâ€™s Mindset Shift
entry.summary: âš¡ Premium Deal: ðŸš€ AI SaaS Builder Bundle + 7,000+ GitHub Projects â€” Launch AI tools swiftly with this curated kit. Instant download. One-time price (less than a coffee). Weâ€™ve been taught to code like engineers. Precise. Rigid. Structured. But what if thatâ€™s the wrong metaphor? What if software isnâ€™t something we â€œconstructâ€â€¦ cultivate? Let me convince you: Software is a garden. You are a gardener. radically change how you write, maintain, and love your code. When we treat coding like engineering, we expect: Clean blueprints before we start Predictable timelines One-time builds and handoffs Finite scopes and exact specs But real-world software: Evolves constantly Breaks in unexpected places Is abandoned, revived, forked, reused Never really â€œfinishesâ€ Software behaves more like a living tâ€¦

entry.title: Sui validators vote on $162M Cetus recovery plan to restore user funds
entry.summary: Sui-based decentralized exchange Cetus may be one step closer to recovering funds lost in a recent exploit, pending the outcome of a community governance vote scheduled to end June 3. Cetus was exploited for over $220 million worth of digital assets on May 22. Shortly after the incident, Cetus managed to freeze $162 million of the funds. In a May 27 post on X, Sui said Cetus had requested a community vote to approve the recovery of the frozen funds. â€œIf the community vote is approved, the funds will be recovered from the attacker and held in a multisig trust account until they can be returned to accounts that had positions in Cetus,â€ the post said. The vote is part of a broader recovery plan that includes using Cetusâ€™s treasury and securing an emergency loan from the Sui Foundation. Souâ€¦

entry.title: IMF says El Salvador to make â€˜effortsâ€™ to stop Bitcoin buys with $120M payments deal
entry.summary: The International Monetary Fund said it has reached an agreement with El Salvador to pay the country $120 million following an initial review of its $1.4 billion loan agreement struck last year. The IMF said on May 27 that as part of the deal, El Salvador will need to fulfill its prior obligations around limiting further government involvement in Bitcoin (BTC), and it will have to cease its involvement in the Chivo wallet by the end of July. â€œOn Bitcoin, efforts will continue to ensure that the total amount of Bitcoin held across all government-owned wallets remains unchanged,â€ the global lender said. The planned payout, subject to IMF executive board approval, is part of a larger $1.4 billion, 40-month loan deal struck in December, which saw El Salvador agree to confine its Bitcoin ambitiâ€¦

entry.title: Real-world assets could revitalize dying NFT lending market: DappRadar
entry.summary: Real-world assets linking up with non-fungible tokens (NFTs) is one of a few key catalysts that could reignite the waning NFT lending sector, which is suffering from a collapse in volumes and user activity, says blockchain analytics platform DappRadar. Volumes in the NFT lending market, which allows NFT holders to take out a loan against their token, have dropped 97% from a peak of around $1 billion in January 2024 to $50 million in May, DappRadar analyst Sara Gherghelas said in a May 27 report. Gherghelas said for NFT lending to â€œmove beyond survival mode,â€ it needs â€œnew catalystsâ€ to reignite the sector, such as real-world asset NFTs, like tokenized real estate or yield-bearing assets that could unlock more stable, trusted collateral sources. â€œSo far, 2025 has not delivered a compelling â€¦

entry.title: Nasdaq files for 21Shares Sui ETF, kicking off SEC review
entry.summary: Nasdaq has filed for crypto asset manager 21Shares to list a spot Sui exchange-traded fund (ETF) in the US, initiating the Securities and Exchange Commissionâ€™s review process. The stock marketâ€™s May 23 19b-4 filing, which asks the SEC to list the 21Shares SUI ETF, follows 21Sharesâ€™ April 30 submission of its S-1 registration statement to the SEC, which asked the regulator to approve trading of the proposed fund. Both regulatory filings are needed for the Sui (SUI) tracking fund to go live, with the 19b-4 filing kicking off the SECâ€™s review process. The agency must decide whether to accept, reject or delay the application within 45 days and it can delay its decision multiple times, for a maximum review period of 240 days. The SEC must decide on 21Sharesâ€™ application by Jan. 18, 2026, at theâ€¦

entry.title: Growing BTC reserve requires Congressional legislation â€” VanEck exec
entry.summary: Building a permanent US strategic Bitcoin reserve would likely require targeted legislation rather than executive action, according to VanEckâ€™s head of digital assets, Matthew Sigel. Speaking at Bitcoin 2025 in Las Vegas, Sigel said the most viable path forward may involve inserting Bitcoin mining incentives into the congressional budget reconciliation process. According to Sigel, the most effective path to growing a US strategic Bitcoin reserve would be through targeted amendments to congressional budget legislation. These could include tax credits for mining companies that use methane gas and other incentives aimed at encouraging miners to share a portion of their mined BTC with the federal government. He argued that such an approach would allow the reserve to grow organically over timeâ€¦

The acquisitions would be financed using existing funds within the Federal Reserve System and the Treasury Department.Â As Cointelegraph reported, the Trump administration has reiterated the need to use â€œbudget-neutraâ€¦

entry.summary: Selling Bitcoin is like â€œplaying in a really bad house-rate casino,â€ according to Adam Back, CEO of Blockstream and one of Bitcoinâ€™s earliest adopters. In a recent interview with Bitcoin financial services firm Unchained, Back said the odds are stacked against traders trying to time the market. Back came to this conclusion in the early days of Bitcoin, he said, when the price â€œwas going up basically exponentially but it [was] extremely volatile.â€ â€œSo [...] if you see something thatâ€™s going up exponentially but with volatility, if you sell it to time the market a bit falling, the odds are against you,â€ Back said, adding: â€œThe trend line is up and to the right, exponential, and so thereâ€™s extremely bad trading odds attached to selling because youâ€™re really hoping that it falls.â€ Adam Back duâ€¦

entry.title: 93% of all Bitcoin is already mined. Hereâ€™s what that means
entry.summary:
How much Bitcoin is left to mine?
Bitcoinâ€™s total supply is hardcoded at 21 million BTC, a fixed upper limit that cannot be altered without a consensus-breaking change to the protocol. This finite cap is enforced at the protocol level and is central to Bitcoinâ€™s value proposition as a deflationary asset. As of May 2025, approximately 19.6 million Bitcoin (BTC) have been mined, or about 93.3% of the total supply. That leaves roughly 1.4 million BTC yet to be created, and those remaining coins will be mined very slowly. The reason for this uneven distribution is Bitcoinâ€™s exponential issuance schedule, governed by an event called the halving. When Bitcoin launched in 2009, the block reward was 50 BTC. Every 210,000 blocks â€” or approximately every fouâ€¦

entry.title: ZKPs can prove I'm old enough without telling you my age
entry.summary: Opinion by: Andre Omietanski, General Counsel, and Amal Ibraymi, Legal Counsel at Aztec Labs What if you could prove you're over 18, without revealing your birthday, name, or anything else at all? Zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) make this hypothetical a reality and solve one of the key challenges online: verifying age without sacrificing privacy.Â The need for better age verification today We're witnessing an uptick in laws being proposed restricting minors' access to social media and the internet, including in Australia, Florida, and China. To protect minors from inappropriate adult content, platform owners and governments often walk a tightrope between inaction and overreach.Â For example, the state of Louisiana in the US recently enacted a law meant to block minors from viewing porn. Sitesâ€¦
